docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
The mkdocs.yml file contains all the configuration for your documentation project.

site_name: My Docs
nav:
    - Home: index.md
    - User Guide: user-guide.md
    - About: about.md

The site_name variable sets the name of your documentation project. The nav variable defines the structure of your site and the order in which the pages are displayed. Each item in the nav list is a link to a markdown file. The key is the name of the link and the value is the path to the markdown file relative to the docs directory.

docs.title: Writing your docs
docs.text: MkDocs uses Markdown for writing your documentation. Markdown is a lightweight markup language that you can use to add formatting elements to your text. You can use it to add headings, paragraphs, lists, links, images, code blocks, and more.

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
To create a heading, add a # symbol followed by a space and the heading text. The number of # symbols corresponds to the level of the heading.

# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3
#### Heading 4
##### Heading 5
###### Heading 6

docs.title: Paragraphs
docs.text:
To create a paragraph, just add some text. Paragraphs are separated by a blank line.

This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
To create a list, use the - or + symbol followed by a space for each item in the list.

- Item 1
- Item 2
- Item 3

To create a nested list, indent the items by four spaces or one tab.

- Item 1
  - Subitem 1
  - Subitem 2
- Item 2

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
To create a link, enclose the link text in brackets and then add the URL in parentheses.

[Link text](https://example.com)

docs.title: Images
docs.text:
To add an image, use the following syntax:

![Alt text](image.jpg)

docs.title: Code blocks
docs.text:
To add a code block, use the backtick (`) character at the beginning and end of the code block.

```python
def my_function():
    print("Hello, world!")
```

docs.title: Building your site
docs.text: To build your site, run the mkdocs build command in your terminal. This will generate a directory named site that contains all the HTML files for your site. You can then use a web server to serve these files or deploy them to a static hosting service.

docs.title: Deploying your site
docs.text: To deploy your site, you can use a web hosting service like Netlify or GitHub Pages. These services provide a simple way to deploy your documentation site. You can also use a third-party service like ReadTheDocs to host your documentation.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
MkDocs is a fast, simple and powerful static site generator that's geared towards building project documentation. It has many features including auto-generated navigation, search, and support for multiple languages.

Overall, MkDocs is a great choice for building project documentation and it's easy to use and customize.

Happy writing!
